translated: Verses of the Elders
The Collection of Sevens
The First Chapter
The Elder Bhaddiya the Dwarf
In the Ambapālī Grove, others,
Bhaddiya in the forest grove,
Having uprooted craving with its root,

analyzed: tattha bhaddaḥ uva jhāyati  ramante ike mudiṅga ihi
translated: Bhaddiya is radiant right there.🔽Some delight in drums,
in lutes and cymbals,
But I, at the foot of a tree,
delight in the Buddha’s instruction.
If the Buddha would grant me a boon,

original: so ca labbhetha me varo;🔽Gaṇhehaṁ sabbalokassa,
analyzed: so ca labbhetha me varo  gaṇheham sabba lokassa
translated: and if that boon could be obtained by me,🔽I would take up the constant mindfulness
of the body for all the world.
Those who have praised me for my looks,
and those who have followed me for my voice,🔽Those people, full of desire and passion,
do not know me.
He who does not know what is internal,
and does not see what is external,
The fool, completely obstructed,
is carried away by the voice.
He who does not know what is internal,
but sees what is external,
Seeing results externally,
he too is carried away by the voice.
He who knows what is internal,
and sees what is external,
Seeing without obstruction,
he is not carried away by sound.”
… the Elder Bhaddiya the Dwarf …
